Almost everyone who is
involved in student activities
has, at one time or another,
visited Mrs. Jerrie LaPointe's
office--to file a request for
money, to ask for advice or
assistance. Now, after 18 years
of service to Hopkins students,
she feels that it is about time she
got a chance to sleep late and to
have some time to herself. Mrs.
LaPointe plans to retire this
year.
According to her immediate
supervisor, Director of Student
Activities Chris Colombo, Mrs.
LaPointe "handles requests for
Student Activities Commission
expenditures" and keeps records
on how the funds are spent, as
Student Activities Coordinator.
However, her co-workers in the
SAC office confirm that her job
has been to oversee student
activities and to make sure that
everything runs smoothly.

Jerrie LaPointe came to
Hopkins as the secretaiy to the
Dean of Students, Kelso Morrill,
back when the office was
located in the White House. As
Hopkins became larger and the
administrative offices became
more diversified, the Student
Activities Office was moved to a
larger area in Levering Hall.
Although the location and the
title of her job has changed, Mrs.
LaPointe maintains that it has
remained basically the same
because she has always worked
with students and student activities. She says that it is this
aspect of her job that she will
miss most.
Over the years, Mrs. LaPointe
feels that one of the most
favorable changes at Hopkins
was the University's decision
to go co-ed. She believes that
women are dedicated and far
better than men at organizing
activities, tending to details
and keeping records. She has had

many enjoyable moments at
reminisces
and
Hopkins,
especially about various Barnstormers performances and past
Spring Fairs. Scenes such as the
Barnstormers' performance of
Hadrian VI stand out not only
because of the acting but also
because the performers of that
particular show came frantically
to Mrs. LaPointe for help. They
had not yet finished painting a
chair for the set and had no idea
how they would get it to dry
before the show. Unable to solve
their predicament, Mrs. LaPointe
was surprised that the chair was
onstage for the eight o'clock
performance. It turned out that
the actors had used hair dryers!
Memories such as the time she
rode on the float as Spring Fair
Queen have given Mrs. LaPointe
some of her best memories of
Hopkins and its students.

A Fair Party
It is simply difficult to believe the
hypocrisy, sanctimonious self-righteousness, and bald-faced temerity of the
Council members who attempted to
squelch the party for Spring Fair volunSpouting such high-sounding
teers.
phrases as "gross abuse of power," "gross
selfishness," and "conspicuous consumption," they practically fell over one
another in their frenzied attempt to
squelch the satanic celebration lest it
bring the wrath of a budget-conscious
God thundering down upon this campus.
One wonders what bottomless cistern of
nerve they dipped their rusty buckets into
before attempting to deny to others
what they themselves enjoy. Who can
possibly deny that the dollar value of all
the "fringe benefits" which the Council
members enjoy amount to MORE than
the sum asked by the Fair as a just. reward. But of course the Council's perks
aren't "conspicuous consumption," are
they? Of course not, because they are
stretched out over nine months and
hidden under a veil of "official business"
bullshit. In reality, it is only our pop-gun
politico's talent for obfuscation that make
their after-hours get-togethers the status
quo and the Fair's a threat to public
safety.
What these pompous party-poopers
might keep in mind is that, unlike the

Council , students like Spring Fair. The

Fair is a source of happiness, people
enjoy it, and it contributes to this University's good name. Can the Council
make the same claims?
S2000 is a large piece of change,
but in this case it is justified. The many
people who volunteered for Spring Fair
have been busting their butts for five
months in order to bring about a fine
thing--not only for Hopkins, but for
Baltimore and the entire state as well. To
now use them as scapegoats so that
certain Council members can loudly
proclaim their "fiscal responsibility"
would be to see deserving, dedicated
people get a truely royal screwing. A
night out after a job well done is not too
much to ask—on the contrary, it is far too
modest.
Up until now one of the reasons
why Spring Fair has been able to thrive is
that it has been kept above the quagmire
of student politics. Will this change
in the future? Will S.C. meddling become
part and parcel of subsequent fairs?
Vlust the Council be begged? Must they
be implored to keep their incompetent
fingers out of the nation's largest student-run event? Please, folks...please...
don't reach out and bestow your by-now-famous "Touch of Death" upon our
Spring Fair. We would miss it terribly.
